name: Tuna Hash With Dill
author: Ben S.
summary: One of my favorite things to order when I go out to breakfast is hash - corned beef, roast beef or any other variation - which got me to thinking about trying to make it at home. After all, the ingredients are simple: As long as you've got some kind of protein, potatoes and onions, you're in business. And it makes a fast brunch or even light supper dish, with or without poached eggs.
ingredients: 1 ½ pounds starchy potatoes (such as Idaho), cut into 1/2-inch dice
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
directions: oil over low heat in a 12-inch non-stick skillet (so potatoes don't stick)
While skillet heats, prepare onion and tuna as directed above
A few minutes before cooking, increase heat to medium-high
When oil starts to send up wisps of smoke, add onion and tuna; cook, stirring often, until golden brown
Meanwhile, dice potatoes and toss with remaining oil
Transfer tuna mixture to a bowl and reserve
Add potatoes to empty skillet; cook, stirring only occasionally so they form a golden-brown crust, about 10 minutes
As potatoes cook, mix ketchup, mustard, fresh dill and 2 Tbs
(Recipe can be prepared to this point up to 2 hours ahead
Spread hot potatoes on a large lipped cookie sheet; cover when cool
Return skillet to medium-high; add potatoes and re-crisp
) Return reserved tuna mixture to skillet; stir in ketchup mixture, then season with salt and pepper
Cook, stirring frequently, until hash has nicely browned, about 5 minutes longer
